title: System Design & Architecture
content:
Module 7, Lesson 1: System Design & Architecture

Introduction

System design is the discipline of translating requirements into a coherent technical architecture. It involves trade-offs between consistency and availability, latency and throughput, development speed and maintainability. Senior engineers are distinguished not by how fast they code, but by how well they design systems that survive growth.

Key Concepts

Scalability Patterns

Vertical scaling adds resources to a single machine (more RAM, faster CPU). Horizontal scaling adds more machines. Horizontal scaling requires stateless services, load balancers, and distributed data stores. Caching (Redis, CDN) reduces load on origin servers. Message queues (RabbitMQ, SQS) decouple services and absorb traffic spikes.

Microservices vs Monolith

A monolith packages all functionality in one deployable unit — simple to develop and debug initially. Microservices decompose the application into independently deployable services — each with its own database, language, and deployment cadence. Microservices introduce distributed systems complexity; adopt them only when the monolith's bottlenecks are clear.

CAP Theorem

In a distributed system you can guarantee only two of three: Consistency, Availability, Partition tolerance. Since network partitions are inevitable, you must choose between CP (consistent but may be unavailable) and AP (always available but may return stale data).

Summary

Good system design starts with requirements: read/write ratios, data volume, latency SLAs, consistency needs. Sketch the data flow. Identify bottlenecks. Apply patterns judiciously. Document trade-offs explicitly.

quiz.question: What is the difference between vertical and horizontal scaling?
options: Vertical scaling adds more servers; horizontal scaling upgrades existing hardware
Vertical scaling adds resources to one machine; horizontal scaling adds more machines
They are the same concept with different names
Vertical scaling is for databases; horizontal scaling is for web servers

quiz.question: What does the CAP theorem state?
options: A distributed system can guarantee Consistency, Availability, and Partition tolerance simultaneously
A distributed system can guarantee only two of: Consistency, Availability, Partition tolerance
Consistency always takes priority over Availability
Partition tolerance is optional in distributed systems

quiz.question: What is a message queue used for in system design?
options: Storing user messages in a chat application
Caching frequently accessed data
Decoupling services and absorbing traffic spikes asynchronously
Balancing load between web servers

quiz.question: When should you prefer a monolith over microservices?
options: Always — microservices are never appropriate
When you have a large team and well-defined service boundaries
In early stages when simplicity and development speed matter most
Only for mobile applications

quiz.question: What is the primary role of a load balancer?
options: To encrypt traffic between client and server
To store session data for multiple servers
To distribute incoming requests across multiple server instances
To cache static assets at the network edge
